I.      INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will aid policy research and capacity 
building  in  Yunnan  and  Guizhou  provinces  to  promote  sustainable  trade  and  investment 
facilitation, as well as economic linkages, between the two provinces and the Greater Mekong 
Subregion (GMS). For Yunnan, a road map will be prepared to improve its policy, regulations, 
and  institutions  to  facilitate  trade  and  investment  with  the  GMS  and  promote  sustainable 
development  by  integrating  environmental,  social,  and  governance  (ESG)  principles  in  the 
province’s investment promotion activities. For Guizhou, the TA will assess its potential for 
developing  economic  corridors  with  the  GMS,  and  initiate  innovations  in  green  finance 
mobilization to improve the financial and environmental sustainability of its infrastructure projects, 
including those that link it with Guangxi and Yunnan. 
 
2.  The TA will support the strategic objective of the 13th five-year plan, 2016–2020 of the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) to further open up the country’s economy 
and enhance the quality of its economic growth.1 The plan calls for the PRC to break new ground 
in strengthening cross-border cooperation, and Yunnan and Guizhou have been identified as 
pivotal to doing so. The TA is aligned with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership 
strategy  for  the  PRC,  2016–2020  and  Strategy  2030’s  operational  priorities  to  enhance 
environmental sustainability and foster regional cooperation and integration.2 
 
II.      ISSUES 
 
3.  Yunnan is an active participant in the GMS Economic Cooperation Program. Yunnan’s 
trade with the other five GMS countries grew by 5.6% in 2018. To reap the benefits of a continued 
expansion and deepening of economic cooperation with the GMS, Yunnan needs to upgrade its 
cross-border trade and investment facilitation systems. Market access restrictions and unfriendly 
business  processes  must  be  addressed.  This  requires  improvements  to  (i)  align  customs, 
immigration, and quarantine border clearance processes with international best practices; (ii) 
promote cross-border trade in services and tourism to complement trade in goods; (iii) implement 
the “national treatment” provisions of the new Foreign Investment Law (FIL), 2020 for foreign 
investors; and (iv) establish governance mechanisms for investors that focus on transparency, 
fair treatment, and communication channels. Further, the coronavirus disease pandemic has 
highlighted new challenges that must be addressed in the cross-border movement of goods and 
peoples. These include (i) health surveillance systems to contain and mitigate the spread of 
contagious diseases, and (ii) food safety and security to avoid disruptions in the food supply chain 
and ensure the seamless flow of essential food commodities. 
 
4.  In 2019, Yunnan was designated a pilot free trade zone (FTZ) to boost the efficiency of its 
economy. The province intends to use its FTZ status to modernize its trade and investment 
facilitation systems and processes. Further, Yunnan needs to strengthen its capacity to implement 
the PRC’s FIL, which took effect in January 2020. The FIL mandates provincial governments to 
promote  an  open  and  transparent  business  environment  and  good  governance  to  ensure 
equitable treatment of foreign and domestic investors. Additionally, Yunnan will need to make its 
economy more sustainable by integrating ESG principles in its investment promotion activities;

5.  Guizhou aims to take advantage of its proximity to the PRC’s two GMS provinces— 
Guangxi and Yunnan—to expand its economic connections with Southeast Asia. Given its rich 
natural and environmental resources, Guizhou was chosen as a pilot green finance zone (GFZ) 
in 2017 to support the PRC’s green transformation goals. Guizhou’s role as a pilot GFZ obligates 
it to achieve stronger economic ties and cooperation with the GMS in ways that are sustainable. 
Consideration of regional public good (RPG) elements must be incorporated into the planning and 
design of connectivity infrastructure investments that it needs to undertake to expand economic 
linkages with the GMS countries. These include the protection of the province’s biodiversity and 
culture, ecological sustainability, and mitigation of health risks. 
 
6.  In line with its pilot GFZ status, Guizhou plans to mobilize green finance in innovative ways 
to improve the financial and environmental sustainability of its infrastructure projects, including 
those that link it with Guangxi and Yunnan, and prospectively with the GMS countries and beyond. 
The Guizhou Provincial Government has provided private financial intermediaries and investors 
with practical incentives to expand green finance, such as direct subsidies and tax benefits. New 
provincial guidelines were issued in 2016 to encourage financial institutions to play a part in 
building the local green economy. However, the province still faces major challenges. It lacks the 
capacity to adapt green finance policies to local conditions. It also needs to learn about green 
finance best practices and ways to apply them to ensure that its infrastructure projects are 
designed and implemented in an environmentally sustainable and socially responsible way. 
 
III.     THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: sustainable cooperation between the PRC’s 
Yunnan and Guizhou provinces and the GMS countries enhanced (footnote 1). The TA will have 
the following outcome: sustainable trade and investment facilitation and cross-border connectivity 
policies and initiatives enhanced.3 By 2024, policies, regulations, and institutions for trade and 
investment facilitation with the GMS based on the TA recommendations will have been adopted 
by  the  Yunnan  Provincial  Government.  It  is  also  envisaged  that  economic  and  transport 
connectivity  initiatives  between  Guizhou  and  the  GMS  will  have  been  implemented,  and 
guidelines for mobilizing green financing for sustainable infrastructure will have been adopted by 
the Guizhou Provincial Government. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Road map on sustainable trade and investment cooperation with Greater 
Mekong  Subregion  for  Yunnan  prepared.  The  road  map  will  identify  obstacles  and  the 
corresponding solutions in Yunnan’s policy, regulations, and institutions to facilitate trade and 
investment cooperation with the GMS, covering the areas of (i) customs, immigration, and 
quarantine processes; (ii) cross-border movement of people for trade in services and tourism; (iii) 
FIL implementation to create equal treatment for domestic and foreign investors; and (iv) adoption 
of ESG principles and indicators by enterprises in the FTZ. The road map will be prepared through 
a  combination  of  desk  research  and  consultations  with  the  central,  provincial,  and  local 
government  stakeholders  to  reflect  their  inputs  and  foster  ownership  of  the  TA  project’s 
 
3  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
recommendations. The TA project’s recommendations on improvements in cross-border trade 
and investment facilitation, as well as innovative approaches to FIL implementation, will be 
submitted to the Yunnan Provincial Government. The road map will be published once endorsed 
by the provincial government. At least two innovations in trade and investment facilitation will be 
piloted with GMS countries. Guidelines on ESG disclosure for firms in the Yunnan FTZ will be 
prepared and disseminated. 
 
9.  Output 2: Infrastructure and economic linkages between Guizhou and the Greater 
Mekong Subregion identified. The TA will assess the potential for creating economic corridors 
between Guizhou and the GMS by reviewing the province’s ongoing and planned economic and 
transport connectivity initiatives to determine how these may complement such economic corridor 
development. To strengthen Guizhou’s capacity as a GFZ, the TA will develop guidelines for 
incorporating RPG and ESG considerations in the design of sustainable infrastructure projects for 
the economic corridors to mobilize green finance. These will include protection of the province’s 
biodiversity and culture, ecological sustainability, and mitigation of health risks. A road map will 
be prepared for Guizhou to guide its efforts to advance and improve on existing initiatives for 
mobilizing green finance, including for sustainable infrastructure projects. The road map will be 
published once endorsed by the Guizhou Provincial Government. By identifying ways to mobilize 
green finance for infrastructure projects, the TA will help amplify environmentally responsible 
investment and environmentally sustainable connectivity between Guizhou and the GMS. 
 
10.  Output 3: Capacity, institutions, knowledge, and skills related to regional public 
goods; environmental, social, and governance principles; and green finance in Yunnan 
and Guizhou provinces enhanced. The knowledge generated from the TA will be shared at 
learning  and  knowledge-sharing  events  on  RPGs,  ESG  principles,  and  green  finance  for 
sustainable infrastructure that will be conducted to increase awareness and understanding of 
these topics by Yunnan and Guizhou officials. The events will also serve as a platform for 
participants from the two provinces and the GMS to discuss mutually beneficial collaboration 
initiatives. The TA will support training to prepare officials of the two provinces to implement the 
TA recommendations. The training for Yunnan  officials will focus on trade and investment 
facilitation with the GMS, and that for Guizhou officials will focus on green financing for sustainable 
infrastructure. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and (ii) $450,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund.4 The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
12.  The provincial governments of Guizhou and Yunnan will provide counterpart support in 
the form of the remuneration and travel expenses of counterpart staff; provision of government 
data  and  studies  to  the  TA  consultants;  provision  of  meeting  rooms,  office  facilities,  and 
geographic information system maps; and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  As the TA has regional dimensions and involves two provinces, ADB will be the executing 
agency. The implementing agency for output 1 will be the Yunnan Provincial Government,

the overall TA implementation and be the implementing agency for output 3. The implementation

IV.     THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis to the 
People’s Republic of China for Enhancing the Sustainable Cooperation of Yunnan and Guizhou 
with the Greater Mekong Subregion, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
